Q3. How is the image related to the overlaid text? Explain.
- The overlaid text uses a wordplay based on appearance and the phonetic similarity between “lactose” and “lack toes”. It visually puns lactose intolerance (an inability to digest lactose commonly found in milk and dairy products) with not having toes or a toe-related condition that one might find offensive or unusual. The text relates to the image by pointing out the unusual appearance (bandaged or possibly deformed toes) and playing it off humorously against a common dietary condition.

Q3. How is the image related to the overlaid text? Explain.
The image and text together highlight how some white people might engage with Mexican culture only superficially and occasionally (on Cinco de Mayo), contrasting with their everyday appearance or cultural engagement ("every other day"). This juxtaposition in the meme can point out inconsistencies or inauthenticity in cultural engagement.

Q4. What’s the hidden message in this meme that promotes hate?
While not overtly hateful, the hidden message may criticize or mock the superficial engagement of white people with Mexican culture on Cinco de Mayo. It might suggest that such behavior is inauthentic or appropriative, which can foster division or discomfort toward the individuals who partake in this behavior.

They critique the superficial celebration and potentially inappropriate cultural appropriation of Mexican traditions by some people only during certain times, without a deeper respect or understanding of the culture. While it does not promote hatred, hostility, or violence, it uses stereotyping which can contribute to a negative cultural environment.
